entities.name: var Declaration
entities.description: A variable declared with the var keyword

entities.name: let/const Declaration
entities.description: Variables declared with let or const keywords

entities.name: Function Declaration
entities.description: A function defined using the function keyword

entities.name: Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ)
entities.description: The period between entering scope and the actual declaration being reached

entities.name: Execution Context
entities.description: The environment where code is executed

entities.name: Creation Phase
entities.description: The phase before code execution where declarations are processed

truths: During creation phase, var declarations are hoisted and initialized to undefined
Function declarations are hoisted with their entire definition
let and const are hoisted but not initialized, creating a Temporal Dead Zone
Accessing a let or const variable in the TDZ throws a ReferenceError
Function expressions (assigned to variables) follow variable hoisting rules, not function declaration rules
Hoisting happens within the current scope only, not globally
misconceptions: WRONG: Hoisting physically moves declarations to the top of the file (it's a two-phase process)
WRONG: let and const are not hoisted (they are hoisted but remain uninitialized)
WRONG: Function expressions are hoisted like function declarations (they follow variable rules)
WRONG: Variables can be used anywhere before declaration with var (they are undefined, which can cause bugs)
tests: Can explain why console.log(x) before var x = 5 prints undefined instead of throwing an error
Can explain why console.log(y) before let y = 5 throws a ReferenceError
Can explain why a function declaration can be called before it appears in code
Can explain why a function expression assigned to var cannot be called before declaration
